channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Ranch fire triggers evacuations for residents of Azusa's Mountain Cove community
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Officials issued mandatory evacuation orders Thursday afternoon as the Ranch fire threatened homes in Azusa's Mountain Cove community.
item.content:encoded: Officials issued mandatory evacuation orders Thursday afternoon as the Ranch fire threatened homes in Azusa's Mountain Cove community.

media:content.media:description: Residents of the Mountain Cove community off San Gabriel Canyon Road in Azusa are under evacuation orders as the Ranch fire burns.

item.title: 911 caller in 'swatting' incident at BLM leader's home said he was sending 'message'
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A man who called 911 and falsely claimed to be holding people hostage inside the L.A. home of a prominent Black Lives Matter leader told the LAPD dispatcher he was there to send a message.
item.content:encoded: A man who called 911 and falsely claimed to be holding people hostage inside the L.A. home of a prominent Black Lives Matter leader told the LAPD dispatcher he was there to send a message.

item.title: Dodger Stadium will serve as polling center for general election
item.dc:creator: Jack Harris
item.description: The Dodgers have partnered with LeBron James' voting rights organization to turn Dodger Stadium into a polling center for the general election in November.
item.content:encoded: The Dodgers have partnered with LeBron James' voting rights organization to turn Dodger Stadium into a polling center for the general election in November.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA, WEDNESDAY MARCH 25, 2020 - Aerial views of Dodger Stadium the day before opening day that was postponed due to the Covid 19 pandemic. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Brush fire in West Covina is moving toward homes, officials say
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Firefighters responded Thursday afternoon to a fire in the city of West Covina that is moving towards homes, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters responded Thursday afternoon to a fire in the city of West Covina that is moving towards homes, authorities said.

item.title: California to end eviction protections next month unless lawmakers extend them
item.description: California will resume eviction and foreclosure proceedings on Sept. 1 unless the state Legislature takes action after the court system's rule-making body on Thursday voted to end temporary statewide protections for people who lost their jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: California will resume eviction and foreclosure proceedings on Sept. 1 unless the state Legislature takes action after the court system's rule-making body on Thursday voted to end temporary statewide protections for people who lost their jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Anti-eviction signs decorate the Rodney Drive apartments in Los Feliz.

item.title: L.A. County sues church for violating COVID-19 orders with indoor worship services
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Earlier, Grace Community Church in Sun Valley filed suit against state and county officials, including Gov. Gavin Newsom and L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti.
item.content:encoded: Earlier, Grace Community Church in Sun Valley filed suit against state and county officials, including Gov. Gavin Newsom and L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti.

item.title: Jackie Lacey's husband claims state charges against him in gun case are improper
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: David Lacey, the husband of Los Angeles County's district attorney, seeks to have charges that he pointed a gun at protesters at his door dismissed.
item.content:encoded: David Lacey, the husband of Los Angeles County's district attorney, seeks to have charges that he pointed a gun at protesters at his door dismissed.

media:content.media:description: This video still image provided by Dahlia Ferlito shows Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey's husband David Lacey pointing a gun at Black Lives Matter protesters outside their home in the Granada Hills section of Los Angeles on Monday, March 2, 2020. The first black woman to lead the largest local prosecutor's office in the U.S. apologized for her husband pointing the gun at Black Lives Matter demonstrators who came to their Los Angeles home before dawn Monday. (Dahlia Ferlito via AP)

item.title: Watch: Lake fire spawns 'terrifying' fire tornado as it burns through Angeles National Forest
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The National Weather Service called the Lake fire tornado, or fire whirl, 'an impressive and terrifying example of extreme fire behavior.'
item.content:encoded: The National Weather Service called the Lake fire tornado, or fire whirl, 'an impressive and terrifying example of extreme fire behavior.'

item.title: California oil production limits stall in Legislature, leaving the issue to Newsom
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Legislation to put mandated minimum space between oil wells and homes, as well as schools and playgrounds, failed passage in a California Senate committee.
item.content:encoded: Legislation to put mandated minimum space between oil wells and homes, as well as schools and playgrounds, failed passage in a California Senate committee.

media:content.media:description: McKittrick, California, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 29, 2020-There are over 1,100 producing oil wells in the McKittrick oil field, just north of the town of McKittrick on Cal. State Route 33. With the falling price of oil, some pumpjacks that need repair are being left idle. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Team is researching at-home coronavirus testing, Garcetti says
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: A coalition of scientific experts, bioscience firms, government leaders and foundations is researching at-home coronavirus testing, L.A. mayor says.
item.content:encoded: A coalition of scientific experts, bioscience firms, government leaders and foundations is researching at-home coronavirus testing, L.A. mayor says.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 27: Mayor Eric Garcetti speaks during a press conference to announce the expansion of LAPD's signature community policing program in City Hall on Monday, July 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Suspected MS-13 leader's capture offers window into gang's structure
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Nelson "Mula" Flores, who authorities say is one of MS-13's most influential members outside El Salvador, is taken into U.S. custody.
item.content:encoded: Nelson "Mula" Flores, who authorities say is one of MS-13's most influential members outside El Salvador, is taken into U.S. custody.

media:content.media:description: Nelson Alexander Flores, known as 'Mula,' is charged in Columbus with extortion and money laundering.

item.title: Sheriff Villanueva to fire or suspend 26 people involved in off-duty Banditos fight
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva moves to fire or suspend 26 employees over a 2018 fight associated with the Banditos clique.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva moves to fire or suspend 26 employees over a 2018 fight associated with the Banditos clique.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 12: Sheriff Alex Villanueva speaks at a news conference to give an update on the fatal shooting by a deputy of Andres Guardado on June 18 near Gardena. in Hall of Justice on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California on the cusp of reining in COVID-19 surge, data show
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Statewide in California, the transmission rate of COVID-19 has stabilized or is falling, and hospitalization rates are also dropping.
item.content:encoded: Statewide in California, the transmission rate of COVID-19 has stabilized or is falling, and hospitalization rates are also dropping.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA - AUGUST 09, 2020: People wear protective masks against the coronavirus while making their way along the bicycle path in Venice Beach. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Back to school in a pandemic: Resources and news for parents
item.description: The new school year of remote learning will bring unique challenges. Here are guides to help parents of school-age children navigate remote learning, as well as recent updates about education in Southern California.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Labels on desks designate where students can sit with respect to social distancing as Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: What can parents who work outside the home do about remote schooling?
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Remote learning is a challenge for parents who have to leave home for work. Here's a guide to some of the options
item.content:encoded: Remote learning is a challenge for parents who have to leave home for work. Here's a guide to some of the options

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - APRIL 27: Vons store supervisor Anthony Capone, right, greets shoppers as they are allowed in at 7 a.m. to the Vons located at 24325 Crenshaw Blvd in Torrance. Doors opened at 6 a.m. for seniors and at-risk shoppers due to the Coronavirus. Most of the team arrives at 5 a.m. to stock the shelves with product, sanitize the location for staff and shoppers, and picker/shoppers begin to collect items for .com home delivery shoppers. Vendors arriving throughout the morning must read a checklist of warnings, sign in and they must wear face covering. Vons on Monday, April 27, 2020 in Torrance, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Back to school in a pandemic: The basics of remote learning
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Here's how to get help with technology, including computers, WiFi and free meals, from your school district.
item.content:encoded: Here's how to get help with technology, including computers, WiFi and free meals, from your school district.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - APRIL 23, 2020: Kahlinah (cq) Garrett, an office assistant at Hosler Middle School in Lynwood, helps distribute computers on Thursday, April 23, 2020. Remote digital learning has become a necessity during the coronavirus pandemic. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Strategies for supporting your child's social and emotional learning from home
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Math homework and history reading can mostly be done alone. But social and emotional learning requires interaction. Here's how parents can help their children during remote schooling.
item.content:encoded: Math homework and history reading can mostly be done alone. But social and emotional learning requires interaction. Here's how parents can help their children during remote schooling.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 21, 2020: Samuel Rodas, 40, bottom, plays with his son Adrian Rodas, age 2, left, and daughter Karla Rodas, 4, right, on Father's Day in Griffith Park, CA in Los Angeles, CA June 21, 2020. Samuel was helping his son play in the tree. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fire in Lake Hughes area explodes as firefighters battle to save communities
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Leila Miller
item.description: The Lake fire in the Angeles National Forest started near the 5 Freeway and rapidly spread, moving toward several small communities west of Lancaster.
item.content:encoded: The Lake fire in the Angeles National Forest started near the 5 Freeway and rapidly spread, moving toward several small communities west of Lancaster.

media:content.media:description: LAKE HUGHES CA AUGUST 13, 2020 - The smoldering remains of a home on Pine Canyon Road that was destroyed by the Lake fire Thursday, August 13, 2020. There is 0% containment and the fire has scorched 10,500 acres in the Lake Hughes area. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's migrant farmworkers face evictions with no safety net amid pandemic
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Agricultural and essential workers across California fear evictions as the coronavirus forces them out of work, but many living here illegally are also afraid to seek help or fight back.
item.content:encoded: Agricultural and essential workers across California fear evictions as the coronavirus forces them out of work, but many living here illegally are also afraid to seek help or fight back.

media:content.media:description: Irma Barbosa (right) watches while farmworker advocate Luis Magana looks over eviction papers she received from her landlord in July.

item.title: Beach baptisms draw large gatherings to the shore
item.dc:creator: Times Staff
item.description: Photos: Christian faithful have been gathering, raising their hands skyward and, for some, stepping into the cool Pacific to be baptized.
item.content:encoded: Photos: Christian faithful have been gathering, raising their hands skyward and, for some, stepping into the cool Pacific to be baptized.

media:content.media:description: Corona del Mar, California-July 31, 2020-Amber Strayhand (right) is baptized at Corona Del Mar State Park as a part of Saturate OC. The religious group Saturate OC is made up of over 60 churches from California and beyond, gather at Corona del Mar State Beach, CA, on August 7, 2020, to pray and do baptisms in the ocean. Almost no one in the group was wearing a mask despite the rising cases of coronavirus in California. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: I was a Chinese grad student and lost all of my money in a scam. How could it happen to me?
item.dc:creator: Xinlu Liang
item.description: Newly arrived in the U.S., Xinlu Liang fell victim to a complex scam, one of many that target international students in the U.S. every year.
item.content:encoded: Newly arrived in the U.S., Xinlu Liang fell victim to a complex scam, one of many that target international students in the U.S. every year.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA -AUGUST 03, 2020: Xinlu Liang, 22, a Chinese grad student who lost all her money in a telephone scam, is photographed outside her home in Pasadena. Liang is a freelance writer who finished her master's degree in journalism at USC in May. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A generation left behind? Online learning cheats poor students, Times survey finds
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel, Howard Blume, Ben Poston, Julia Barajas
item.description: Times survey finds profound disparities in distance learning between children attending schools in high-poverty areas and those in more affluent ones.
item.content:encoded: Times survey finds profound disparities in distance learning between children attending schools in high-poverty areas and those in more affluent ones.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 10: Andrew Diaz poses for a portrait a couple weeks before the start of the school year where he will be an 11th grader in Lynwood Park on Monday, Aug. 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The unparalleled disruption of California schools has had profound impacts on students in high-poverty communities. Diaz did not receive a computer to work from home until more than a month after the shutdown and struggled to find motivation to complete schoolwork without the in person interaction. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lake fire: Evacuation zones, road closures, shelters
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Evacuation zones, road closures and shelters for pets and people fleeing the Lake fire in the Santa Clarita Valley.
item.content:encoded: Evacuation zones, road closures and shelters for pets and people fleeing the Lake fire in the Santa Clarita Valley.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CLARITA, CA - AUGUST 12: A plume of smoke from the Lake Fire in Lake Hughes is seen from a pedestrian bridge in Canyon Country in the Santa Clarita Valley on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020. As of early evening, nearly 10,000 acres had burned. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County offering money to renters affected by COVID-19 pandemic
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: The assistance is available to residents who live outside of the city of Los Angeles, with much of the money being directed to specific zip codes identified as especially in need of relief.
item.content:encoded: The assistance is available to residents who live outside of the city of Los Angeles, with much of the money being directed to specific zip codes identified as especially in need of relief.

media:content.media:description: EL MONTE, CA - MARCH 29: Rodolfo Cortes, 30, of El Monte and other tenant rights activists assemble at the El Monte City Hall to demand that the El Monte City Council pass an eviction moratorium barring all evictions during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, March 29, 2020 in El Monte, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD videos show violent clashes with protesters in Fairfax district in May
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Newly released body-camera footage from protests near the Grove in May shines new light on two of the most controversial moments of the unrest.
item.content:encoded: Newly released body-camera footage from protests near the Grove in May shines new light on two of the most controversial moments of the unrest.

item.title: Hot weather is expected into early next week for the Los Angeles region
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: High pressure over the Southwest will bring excessive heat to Southern California, especially inland areas.
item.content:encoded: High pressure over the Southwest will bring excessive heat to Southern California, especially inland areas.

media:content.media:description: Triple-digit high temperatures and warm nights will cause potentially excessive heat lasting into Tuesday for inland areas.

item.title: Airbnb to pursue legal action after unauthorized party in Sacramento County
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Airbnb will for the first time be taking legal action against a guest for violating its ban on unauthorized parties, the company said Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Airbnb will for the first time be taking legal action against a guest for violating its ban on unauthorized parties, the company said Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: Academic research has found discrimination among Airbnb hosts against guests with black-sounding names.

item.title: California sees decrease in coronavirus hospitalizations as test backlog boosts number of confirmed cases
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: While hospitalizations rates decline, deaths are increasing and officials warn that Californians need to continue following safety protocols to prevent another wave of infections.
item.content:encoded: While hospitalizations rates decline, deaths are increasing and officials warn that Californians need to continue following safety protocols to prevent another wave of infections.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 08: A man fishes as others enjoy a summer day at the lake in Kenneth Hahn Lower Park in Los Angeles during the coronavirus pandemic Saturday, Aug. 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 10,000-acre brush fire burns near Lake Hughes; mandatory evacuations ordered
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The Lake fire has burned 10,000 acres near North Lake Hughes Road and Pine Canyon Road in the Angeles National Forest.
item.content:encoded: The Lake fire has burned 10,000 acres near North Lake Hughes Road and Pine Canyon Road in the Angeles National Forest.

media:content.media:description: The Lake Hughes fire burns vehicles in Angeles National Forest.

item.title: Newsom defends economic recovery efforts and task force amid criticism about transparency
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The governor's defense of his administration's recovery efforts, including the work of a 108-member all-star economic task force, came as the state released updated figures on COVID-19 infections that reflect numbers from a massive backlog of cases that were unreported because of a computerized data system failure.
item.content:encoded: The governor's defense of his administration's recovery efforts, including the work of a 108-member all-star economic task force, came as the state released updated figures on COVID-19 infections that reflect numbers from a massive backlog of cases that were unreported because of a computerized data system failure.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Officials say no evidence links Andres Guardado to incidents where deputy shot him
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: L.A. County Sheriff Villanueva gives an update regarding the shooting of Andres Guardado.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County Sheriff Villanueva gives an update regarding the shooting of Andres Guardado.

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CALIFORNIA - JUNE 21: Hundreds of people rallied and marched outside the Compton Sheriffs' Office in protest for the shooting of Andres Guardado, security guard who was fatally shot by a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy on Sunday, June 21, 2020 in Gardena, California. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. father whose tip exposed Singer's college admissions scandal gets one year in prison
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The L.A. financier whose tip exposed William "Rick" Singer's college admissions scam is sentenced to one year in prison for securities fraud.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. financier whose tip exposed William "Rick" Singer's college admissions scam is sentenced to one year in prison for securities fraud.

media:content.media:description: Morrie Tobin.

item.title: Mexican Consulate in L.A. opens new coronavirus testing center
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The testing center was opened in an effort to better serve Latinos, who have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The testing center was opened in an effort to better serve Latinos, who have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 12: Medical Assistant Marianne Orantes, right, prepares to see participants for COVID-19 testing at the Consulate General of Mexico office in Los Angeles after Los Angeles County Supervisor Hilda L. Solis and The Consul General of Mexico Marcela Celorio held a press conference to announce a new COVID-19 testing site at the Mexican Consulate office in Los Angeles.The free testing site opened August 12, 2020 with data revealing that Latinos in L.A. County have been disproportionately impacted by COVID-19. Tests will be administered at this location five days a week with more than 1,500 tests to be administered weekly. Los Angeles on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California coronavirus deaths double, with rural areas and suburbs hit hard
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee
item.description: The weekly death toll in California among COVID-19 patients is nearly twice its previous high in April as more cases shift to rural and suburban areas.
item.content:encoded: The weekly death toll in California among COVID-19 patients is nearly twice its previous high in April as more cases shift to rural and suburban areas.

media:content.media:description: ONTARIO, CA -JULY24: San Bernardino County Health Department LVN Elizabeth McKinnon explains how to self-swab for COVID-19 test to Glenda Guerra at a coronavirus testing site at Ontario Convention Center. Ontario Convention Center on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Ontario, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD probes likely 'swatting' call after descending on home of Black Lives Matter activist
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Police told Melina Abdullah they had received a call saying there was a man holding her family hostage and threatening to kill her. There was not.
item.content:encoded: Police told Melina Abdullah they had received a call saying there was a man holding her family hostage and threatening to kill her. There was not.

item.title: Judge refuses to shut Ventura County church that has defied COVID-19 health order

item.description: Ventura County judge refuses to close Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park and find its pastor in contempt of court for holding indoor services.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County judge refuses to close Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park and find its pastor in contempt of court for holding indoor services.

media:content.media:description: NEWBURY PARK, CA - AUGUST 09: Supporters and protestors gather at Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park for Pastor Rob McCoy who defied a judge's order and held indoor services on Sunday, Aug. 9, 2020 in Newbury Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County declares 8/24 Kobe Bryant Day

item.description: Kobe Bryant Day in Orange County will be Aug. 24, chosen by county supervisors for the jersey numbers 8 and 24 the late Laker wore during his career.
item.content:encoded: Kobe Bryant Day in Orange County will be Aug. 24, chosen by county supervisors for the jersey numbers 8 and 24 the late Laker wore during his career.

media:content.media:description: Kobe Bryant poses with his family after getting his jerseys retired before a game between the Lakers and the Golden State Warriors at Staples Center on Dec. 18, 2017.

item.title: California paid a price for mask shortage in dollars and lives, coronavirus study finds
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: The UC Berkeley Labor Center study urges California officials to stockpile masks, gowns, gloves to avoid shortages seen during the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The UC Berkeley Labor Center study urges California officials to stockpile masks, gowns, gloves to avoid shortages seen during the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Agent details child rape, pornography case against La Luz Del Mundo church leader
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Naason Joaquin Garcia, leader of La Luz Del Mundo, is charged with raping young members of his church. Prosecutors have begun to make their case in court.
item.content:encoded: Naason Joaquin Garcia, leader of La Luz Del Mundo, is charged with raping young members of his church. Prosecutors have begun to make their case in court.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST05: Naason Joaquin Garcia, the leader of the Guadalajara-based La Luz del Mundo church, at his bail hearing held at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inspired by essential workers, young brothers use a 3D printer to make face shields
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Wong
item.description: After seeing the impact of the coronavirus on Filipino healthcare workers, Tenzing and Zubin Carvalho came to the rescue and donated 12,500 face shields to nursing homes, schools and hospitals.
item.content:encoded: After seeing the impact of the coronavirus on Filipino healthcare workers, Tenzing and Zubin Carvalho came to the rescue and donated 12,500 face shields to nursing homes, schools and hospitals.

media:content.media:description: HEMET, CA - AUGUST 7, 2020: Zubin Carvalho, 14, left and his brother Tenzing,12, give boxes of their homemade face shields to Meadowbrook Health Care Center Administrator Mike Elbert and Raji Sandhills, director of nursing, on August 7, 2020 in Hemet, California. The Carvalho's have made more than 12,500 face shields using a 3D printer which they have distributed to frontline workers at schools, hospitals and nursing homes.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A Salvadoran immigrant feared losing his food industry job. Now he's dead of COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Soudi Jiménez
item.description: José Roberto Álvarez worked at one of several food distribution facilities briefly closed by officials after the county said they failed to report COVID-19 outbreaks.
item.content:encoded: José Roberto Álvarez worked at one of several food distribution facilities briefly closed by officials after the county said they failed to report COVID-19 outbreaks.

media:content.media:description: El ingeniero José Roberto Álvarez es recordado por su espíritu dicharachero, narrador de historias y amor al prójimo.

item.title: Across L.A., Black Lives Matter murals appear like billboards for justice
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: The Black Lives Matter movement has inspired murals honoring Black lives and people killed by police brutality. But time poses a threat to the art.
item.content:encoded: The Black Lives Matter movement has inspired murals honoring Black lives and people killed by police brutality. But time poses a threat to the art.

media:content.media:description: The legendary comedy club, The Laugh Factory, offered its parking lot billboard to five artists who painted a 148-foot-long mural in honor of the Black Lives Matter movement. The mural was captured in 3-D using drone photogrammetry. For the full augmented reality experience, click on the link above on an iPhone 8 or later with the latest version of iOS. (Produced by Nani Sahra Walker in partnership with the Yahoo News XR Partner Program)

item.title: Commentary: Museums are closed, but you'll find respite in UCLA's remarkable sculpture garden
item.dc:creator: Christopher Knight
item.description: Some big names are here: Matisse, Arp, Bourdelle, Calder, Miró, Noguchi, Voulkos — a remarkable collection that rambles over five acres.
item.content:encoded: Some big names are here: Matisse, Arp, Bourdelle, Calder, Miró, Noguchi, Voulkos — a remarkable collection that rambles over five acres.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CA - AUGUST 8, 2020: Visitors pass by Joan Miro's "Ubu" in the Franklin D. Murphy Sculpture Garden at UCLA in Westwood, CA. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California voters overwhelmingly support sweeping police reforms, new poll finds
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A new poll shows that a majority of Californians support sweeping reforms to law enforcement — including measures that would make it easier to prosecute and sue police officers.
item.content:encoded: A new poll shows that a majority of Californians support sweeping reforms to law enforcement — including measures that would make it easier to prosecute and sue police officers.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: LAPD and peaceful demonstrators moving around Hollywood, CA continue today. The demonstrators are protesting police brutality and racial discrimination in Los Angeles, CA June 2, 2020. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In her native California, Kamala Harris VP pick brings excitement and doubts
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown, Marisa Gerber, Andrea Castillo, Susanne Rust
item.description: Kamala Harris, long influential in California political circles, is now on the ticket as vice president.
item.content:encoded: Kamala Harris, long influential in California political circles, is now on the ticket as vice president.

media:content.media:description: Democratic presidential candidate former Vice President Joe Biden, left, and Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif. shake hands after a Democratic presidential primary debate hosted at Texas Southern University in Houston.

item.title: 'I've now dipped into the pie.' Will COVID-19 change Americans' views of the social safety net?
item.dc:creator: Marisa Gerber
item.description: As more Americans benefit from federal aid during the pandemic, some believe the discourse about the role of government in U.S. life could shift.
item.content:encoded: As more Americans benefit from federal aid during the pandemic, some believe the discourse about the role of government in U.S. life could shift.

media:content.media:description: ENCINITAS, CA - AUGUST 04: Jim Brady, center, CEO of AToN, a rehab company that he started with his wife, Patricia Brady, left, more than a decade ago, and their daughter, Pat, chief operating officer, at the AToN Center, a luxury drug and alcohol addiction treatment center in Encinitas Tuesday, Aug. 4, 2020. As the coronavirus charted its deadly path across the country, Brady decided to temporarily stop accepting clients from some East Coast hot spots and drastically cut client capacity so patients didn't have to share bathrooms. Before long, he was losing a ton of money but he was determined not to layoff any employees. Instead, he applied for and got a PPP loan for about $800,000 from the federal government to cover payroll and a few other things. The experience of accepting government funds has prompted Brady to rethink some of his views on government aid - something he never expected to need. But now that he's watched the positive ripple effect of having received the loan - how it helped him, his family, his employees and their families - his more rigid views of government assistance have started to evolve. "I have a very different eye to that now. I've now dipped into the pie." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Magnitude 3.9 earthquake hits near Clearlake, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.9 earthquake was reported Wednesday morning at 4:45 a.m. 11 miles from Clearlake, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: The earthquake occurred 22 miles from Santa Rosa, Calif.

item.title: Column: In California Sen. Kamala Harris, Biden chooses a VP hailing from our most diverse state

item.description: California is also a state of immigrants. And fittingly, Sen. Kamala Harris is the daughter of immigrant parents — a father from Jamaica, a mother from India.
item.content:encoded: California is also a state of immigrants. And fittingly, Sen. Kamala Harris is the daughter of immigrant parents — a father from Jamaica, a mother from India.

Kamala Harris, D-Calif., as her husband Douglas Emhoff, looks on during a a mock swearing in ceremony in the Old Senate Chamber on Capitol Hill in Washington, Tuesday, Jan. 3, 2017, as the 115th Congress begins. (AP Photo/Kevin Wolf)

item.title: L.A. school board approves deal on remote learning; critics say it falls short on teaching
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: L.A. Board of Education approves agreement with union for structured online teaching. Critics say it needlessly shortens the traditional school day.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Board of Education approves agreement with union for structured online teaching. Critics say it needlessly shortens the traditional school day.

As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. item.title: Amid COVID-19 pandemic, people with diabetes struggle to get insulin
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Wong
item.description: One in four people with diabetes have rationed supplies to cut the cost of their diabetes care since the start of the pandemic, a survey found.
item.content:encoded: One in four people with diabetes have rationed supplies to cut the cost of their diabetes care since the start of the pandemic, a survey found.

media:content.media:description: VAN NUYS, CA -AUGUST 05, 2020: Diabetes patient Adam Winney is photographed inside his apartment in Van Nuys next to 1000 unit samples of fast acting insulin that he received from his doctor. Winney said that each sample lasts him about 3 weeks. A bill is stuck in the Senate health committee right now that would cap insulin costs to $50 a month. Adam, who is currently unemployed because of the coronavirus outbreak, has been living off of the samples from his doctor since he can't afford to pay $1000 a month for insulin. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

The brothers are among dozens of people who county prosecutors say were falsely labeled as gang members or associates by three LAPD officers from the department's Metropolitan Division. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Vicky Lindsey, Compton's passionate advocate for mothers of homicide victims, dies

media:content.media:description: Activists Vicky Lindsey, center, Pam Carolina, left, and Teresa Haro pose with a billboard showing murder victims in urging a stop to violence in Compton. Lindsey has helped many victims' families since her son was killed 20 years ago

item.title: Newsom tries to quell furor over data errors after administration shakeup
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom faced reporters for the first time since he touted the inaccurate coronavirus data as a positive sign of fewer COVID-19 infections a day before the glitches became public. The governor said he was kept in the dark about the problem, even as state health officials were warning counties about data issues days earlier.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom faced reporters for the first time since he touted the inaccurate coronavirus data as a positive sign of fewer COVID-19 infections a day before the glitches became public. The governor said he was kept in the dark about the problem, even as state health officials were warning counties about data issues days earlier.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. The California Senate's plan to cover a projected budget deficit rejects Gov. Gavin Newsom's proposed cuts to public education and health care programs. Newsom's plan would cut funding for public schools by about $8 billion. The Senate's plan would restore $2.7 billion of those cuts, the rest being deferred to future years. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: Coronavirus surging among children, teenagers in California
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Coronavirus cases among children and teenagers are surging in California, up 150% last month, a rate that outpaces COVID-19 cases overall and establishes minors as a small but growing share of the state's COVID-19 cases.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus cases among children and teenagers are surging in California, up 150% last month, a rate that outpaces COVID-19 cases overall and establishes minors as a small but growing share of the state's COVID-19 cases.

media:content.media:description: Sharon Chavez, 26, use the oral swab on her 7-year-old daughter Melany Garcia to test for Coronavirus the parking lot of a Food4Less Grocery in the Westlake area.

item.title: Swarm of Salton Sea earthquakes sparks worry about the San Andreas fault
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Swarm of Salton Sea earthquakes sparks worry about the San Andreas fault
item.content:encoded: Swarm of Salton Sea earthquakes sparks worry about the San Andreas fault

media:content.media:description: Earthquakes as large as magnitude 4.6 under the Salton Sea are raising concern that a larger earthquake could be unleashed on the San Andreas fault, the southernmost section of which has not ruptured since about 1680.

item.title: Trump's unemployment benefit plan won't work in California, Newsom says

item.content:encoded: Newsom and others called on federal officials to overcome a stalemate involving Congress and the president to provide additional funding for states.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: After record-high deaths, COVID-19 hospitalizations decline in Inland Empire
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Last week, both San Bernardino and Riverside counties reported record single-day tallies of coronavirus-related deaths.
item.content:encoded: Last week, both San Bernardino and Riverside counties reported record single-day tallies of coronavirus-related deaths.

media:content.media:description: SAN BERNARDINO, CA -JULY28: Responding to recent spikes in positive COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations, San Bernardino County is bringing back Alternate Care Sites (ACS) to handle possible hospital overload while ensuring those who need medical care are able to receive it. An initial ACS has been set up in Parking Lot 14 at Arrowhead Regional Medical Center (ARMC) in Colton and is being referred to as the ACS Village. It is comprised of a nursing unit, patient care areas with 32 beds, an Isolation Pod, and a command center for staff breaks. Arrowhead Regional Medical Center on Tuesday, July 28, 2020 in San Bernardino, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: California Highway Patrol investigators said the bus driver did not realize the 26-year-old man had been struck by the bus' rear tire in East L.A.

item.title: This California school is open, 'learning as we go.' Is it a model or a mistake?
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Catholic schools in California are seeking waivers to open for in-person learning. In Nevada County, one has gone back to class.
item.content:encoded: Catholic schools in California are seeking waivers to open for in-person learning. In Nevada County, one has gone back to class.

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, CA - AUGUST 06: China Arkansas, 8, right, of Grass Valley, an incoming third-grader, takes an assessment test while David Pistone, a junior high math and social studies teacher, looks on during a teacher meet and greet at Mount Saint Mary's Academy on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020 in Grass Valley, CA. Mount Saint Mary's Academy, founded 1859, is a private Catholic TK-8th grade school with 160 students and is the oldest catholic school west of the Mississippi. The Academy's first day of class will be Aug. 17th. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Latino workers bear brunt of second wave of COVID-19 in ritzy Marin County
item.dc:creator: Rachel Scheier
item.description: In Marin County, one of the nation's richest, Latinos account for 16% of the population but 75% of coronavirus cases. Many are essential workers.
item.content:encoded: In Marin County, one of the nation's richest, Latinos account for 16% of the population but 75% of coronavirus cases. Many are essential workers.

media:content.media:description: Jennifer Tores, a lifelong resident of the Canal, arrived at the local COVID-19 testing site 8 a.m. to get in line. The neighborhood is one of the most heavily tested communities in the state, say health officials, who are struggling to control the spread of the virus.

item.title: The all-star economic task force advising Newsom during the pandemic remains a mystery
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom's economic task force has operated almost entirely behind closed doors, and those appointed were not required to submit state government financial disclosure forms listing their assets and business interests, which would show potential conflicts.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom's economic task force has operated almost entirely behind closed doors, and those appointed were not required to submit state government financial disclosure forms listing their assets and business interests, which would show potential conflicts.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA -JULY 17, 2020: Jason Ruckart, center, a managing partner at Roy's Restaurant in Woodland Hills, hands chopsticks to customers Nicole Lehning, and her husband Kyle, as they dine outdoors. The Lehning's, visiting from Seattle, Washington, said they are on their honeymoon. Fleming's Prime Steakhouse and Roy's Restaurant, located next to each other, converted the valet parking area into outdoor dining. Due to the coronavirus, the restaurants are only allowed to have outdoor dining and takeout as a safety precaution. Valet parking is also not allowed, only self-parking. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Horrible sequence of mistakes': How bullet train contractors botched a bridge project
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: A bridge that was supposed to take a year is incomplete after four, partly because of corrosion and other problems involving California's high-speed-rail contractors.
item.content:encoded: A bridge that was supposed to take a year is incomplete after four, partly because of corrosion and other problems involving California's high-speed-rail contractors.

media:content.media:description: MADERA, CA - AUGUST 05: A 700 foot bullet train bridge across Road 27, between Road 27 and Club Dr., and the BNSF main line in Madera County had a serious problem with corroded tension strands that broke in December 2019, on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Madera, CA. The California High-Speed Rail Authority is making repairs, though the incident points to seriously underlying problems in the project's management. After the strands (steel cables) broke, construction teams shored up the bridge with falsework. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: California should allow its voters to fill U.S. Senate vacancies — not the governor

item.content:encoded: In California, any vacancy in a statewide elective office can be filled by the governor, subject to legislative confirmation.

item.title: San Quentin State Prison guard dies from coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: There have been 261 confirmed cases of COVID-19 among staff members at San Quentin, but Polanco is the first correctional officer there to die from the illness, according to state prison officials.
item.content:encoded: There have been 261 confirmed cases of COVID-19 among staff members at San Quentin, but Polanco is the first correctional officer there to die from the illness, according to state prison officials.

media:content.media:description: San Quentin State Prison, opened in 1852 on the shore of San Francisco Bay, is the state's oldest prison and home to California's only death row.

item.title: L.A. County reports more than 1,700 new coronavirus cases, many among younger people
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,789 new cases of the coronavirus and 10 deaths.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,789 new cases of the coronavirus and 10 deaths.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JULY 3, 2020: Bicyclists and a runner wear masks as they enjoy the boardwalk at Santa Monica Beach on Friday as all beaches in L.A. County are closed due to the coronavirus pandemic on July 3, 2020 in Santa Monica, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newbury Park church holds indoor services in defiance of judge's order
item.dc:creator: Christopher Goffard
item.description: As many as 150 demonstrators gathered near Newbury Park's Godspeak church, some supporting its defiance of a judge's order, others denouncing the indoor services.
item.content:encoded: As many as 150 demonstrators gathered near Newbury Park's Godspeak church, some supporting its defiance of a judge's order, others denouncing the indoor services.

media:content.media:description: NEWBURY PARK, CA - AUGUST 09: Supporters and protestors gather at Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park for Pastor Rob McCoy who defied a judge's order and held indoor services on Sunday, Aug. 9, 2020 in Newbury Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Firefighters report progress against 32,000-acre Apple fire in Riverside County
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The Apple fire had burned 32,412 acres, destroyed four homes and was 40% contained as of Sunday morning.
item.content:encoded: The Apple fire had burned 32,412 acres, destroyed four homes and was 40% contained as of Sunday morning.

media:content.media:description: BANNING, CA - AUGUST 4, 2020: Scorched terrain surrounds a home off Bluff Street as the Apple fire smolders in the background during the coronavirus pandemic on August 4, 2020 in Banning, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Remains of servicemen who died in California training exercise to be prepared for burial
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: The remains were recovered Friday after the Marines and a sailor went missing near San Clemente Island when their amphibious vehicle sank last month.
item.content:encoded: The remains were recovered Friday after the Marines and a sailor went missing near San Clemente Island when their amphibious vehicle sank last month.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. flag was lowered to half-staff at Park Semper Fi in San Clemente, Calif., on Friday, July 31, 2020. Officials say a military seafaring assault vehicle with 15 Marines and a Navy sailor aboard sank off the coast of Southern California, leaving one of the Marines dead and eight missing. A Marine Corps spokesman says they were traveling in the amphibious assault vehicle from the shores of San Clemente Island to a Navy ship Thursday evening when they reported that the vehicle was taking on water. (Paul Bersebach/The Orange County Register via AP)

item.title: Thousands of online listings are violating L.A.'s new short-term rental law
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Ben Poston
item.description: More than a year after L.A. clamped down on renting homes for short stays, many rental hosts appear to be ignoring the new law.
item.content:encoded: More than a year after L.A. clamped down on renting homes for short stays, many rental hosts appear to be ignoring the new law.

media:content.media:description: An overflow crowd fills the L.A. City Council chamber Thursday as the Planning Commission considered imposing new regulations on Airbnb and other websites.

item.title: Amid COVID-19, California releases some inmates doing time for murder. Advocates push to free more
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Anita Chabria, Kim Christensen
item.description: California has focused on freeing nonviolent offenders to combat the spread of coronavirus in prisons, but some have committed violent crimes.
item.content:encoded: California has focused on freeing nonviolent offenders to combat the spread of coronavirus in prisons, but some have committed violent crimes.

media:content.media:description: Two women hold up a banner before the start of a news conference urging California Gov. Gavin Newsom to release prisoners Thursday, July 9, 2020, in San Quentin, Calif. A group of legislators, advocates, academics, and public health officials gathered at San Quentin State Prison to discuss a COVID-19 outbreak at the facility that has sickened more than 1,400 inmates with six deaths. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: As COVID-19 cases surge, patients are dying at a lower rate. Here's why
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Even with California's death toll from COVID-19 surpassing 10,000, some hope is emerging: Doctors are getting better at saving patients.
item.content:encoded: Even with California's death toll from COVID-19 surpassing 10,000, some hope is emerging: Doctors are getting better at saving patients.

media:content.media:description: MISSION HILLS, CA - JULY 10: Nurses Janil Wise (CQ), left, and Melinda Gruman, right, look over medical chart for a patient who is pregnant and was exposed to a person with COVID-19, in the OB triage tent at Providence Holy Cross Medical Center on Friday, July 10, 2020 in Mission Hills, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Drought continues to expand as the monsoon in the Southwest has been largely a no-show
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: Dry westerly flow over Southern California has kept moisture to the south and east
item.content:encoded: Dry westerly flow over Southern California has kept moisture to the south and east

media:content.media:description: U.S. Drought Monitor data released Thursday show drought expanding in the West.

item.title: Griffith Park's beloved carousel man, Julio Gosdinski, has died at age 49
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: Julio Gosdinski, dead age 49, had worked at the carousel since he was a teenager. He loved it so much, the owner made him co-owner.
item.content:encoded: Julio Gosdinski, dead age 49, had worked at the carousel since he was a teenager. He loved it so much, the owner made him co-owner.

media:content.media:description: Julio Gosdinski in 2015 with one of his happy carousel customers, Juna Nguyen, now 10 years old.

item.title: Trump supporters march in peaceful demonstration in Beverly Hills
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Demonstrators carried "Trump 2020" banners, American flags and signs saying "United We Stand."
item.content:encoded: Demonstrators carried "Trump 2020" banners, American flags and signs saying "United We Stand."

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus hospitalizations continue to decline
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported 2,645 new cases of COVID-19 and 51 related deaths but said hospitalizations continued to decline.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported 2,645 new cases of COVID-19 and 51 related deaths but said hospitalizations continued to decline.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Hermosa Beach adds contract officers from private firm to help enforce mask order
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Hermosa Beach is tapping a private consulting firm for personnel to help its police department enforce an ordinance requiring face coverings.
item.content:encoded: Hermosa Beach is tapping a private consulting firm for personnel to help its police department enforce an ordinance requiring face coverings.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA --APRIL 02, 2020 - A man wearing a face covering skates along Pier Plaza, in Hermosa Beach, CA, during the coronavirus pandemic and current safer-at-home orders from California Gov. Gavin Newsom, April 02, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Final canister of nuclear waste transferred to storage facility at San Onofre
item.dc:creator: ROB NIKOLEWSKI
item.description: The transfer of dozens of canisters of nuclear waste to a dry storage facility at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station wrapped up Friday.
item.content:encoded: The transfer of dozens of canisters of nuclear waste to a dry storage facility at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station wrapped up Friday.

media:content.media:description: The final canister at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station is lowered Friday Aug. 7 into its enclosure at a dry storage facility that houses 73 individual canisters at the plant.
